They use common knowledge and the pattern of silence across rounds. Each philosopher initially sees two dirty foreheads and considers the possibility that they themselves might be clean. If one were clean, then only two would be dirty, and those two would have been able to deduce their status and raise their hands by the second round (using the standard two-person version of the puzzle). When no one raises a hand in the second round, each realizes that this “I am clean” assumption leads to a contradiction. Hence each concludes they must also be dirty, and all three raise their hands in the third round.

individual_answers: They reason about what would have happened in worlds with fewer dirty foreheads. If there were only one dirty person, that person would see two clean foreheads and raise their hand in Round 1. No one does, so each rules out “exactly one dirty.” If there were exactly two dirty people, each dirty one would see one dirty and one clean, realize that the other would have raised their hand in Round 1 if they were the only dirty person, and therefore both would raise their hands in Round 2. When no one raises a hand in Round 2, each of the three concludes that there cannot be exactly two dirty people; therefore they themselves must also be dirty. Thus in Round 3 all three now know their foreheads are dirty and raise their hands.
The three philosophers deduce that their foreheads are dirty because:

They deduce their foreheads are dirty because the silence in the first two rounds eliminates the possibilities that only one or only two of them have dirty foreheads. Since no one raised their hand in Round 1, there must be at least two dirty foreheads; since no one raised their hand in Round 2, there must be at least three. Seeing two dirty foreheads on the others, each philosopher realizes they must be the third dirty one.
answers.majority_answer: They reason about what would have happened in worlds with fewer dirty foreheads. If there were only one dirty person, that person would see two clean foreheads and raise their hand in Round 1. No one does, so each rules out “exactly one dirty.” If there were exactly two dirty people, each dirty one would see one dirty and one clean, realize that the other would have raised their hand in Round 1 if they were the only dirty person, and therefore both would raise their hands in Round 2. When no one raises a hand in Round 2, each of the three concludes that there cannot be exactly two dirty people; therefore they themselves must also be dirty. Thus in Round 3 all three now know their foreheads are dirty and raise their hands.

individual_answers: 1. The maximum possible average of three numbers from 1 to 100 is 100. Therefore, the maximum possible target (2/3 of the average) is 2/3 * 100 ≈ 66.67. Any choice greater than 66.67 is irrational because it is guaranteed to be further from the target than 66.67
